docs.lead_paragraph: As a ban on a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion makes its way through Congress, many of the doctors who provide abortions say they remain confused about what will be banned and fear it will apply to other procedures used in the second trimester of pregnancy. The procedure at issue -- what doctors now call intact dilatation and extraction, or intact D&X -- involves pulling the fetus's legs and torso out of the uterus and then crushing its skull before removing it entirely. It is not known how often it is performed in the United States, but its use is limited to the latter weeks of the second trimester. Even then, it is not always the procedure doctors choose.

headline.main: Possible Ban on Abortion Technique Leaves Doctors Uneasy

docs.abstract: Ban on type of abortion sometimes called partial-birth abortion has been passed by Senate and is likely to pass House of Representatives and be signed by Pres George W Bush; some experts contend procedure is not clearly defined in legislation and doctors could face liability as result of emergency medical decisions made while treating mother; various abortion techniques described; type of banned abortions represent less than one-fifth of 1 percent of all abortions; chart; map; photos (L)
docs.snippet: As a ban on a procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion makes its way through Congress, many of the doctors who provide abortions say they remain confused about what will be banned and fear it will apply to other procedures used in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Last summer's surprising report from a large federal study relegating the use of postmenopausal hormone therapy to short-term relief of symptoms, not long-term health maintenance, left millions of women in a quandary: what should they do to keep their bones from deteriorating to the point of fracture? Despite the serious threats to heart and breast health the study uncovered, there is no question that supplemental estrogen protects bones, largely preventing the rapid loss of bone that occurs in the first three to five years after menopause. The very same loss occurs when postmenopausal women stop taking estrogen, no matter how long they may have been on it.

headline.main: Options for Protecting Bones After Menopause

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column outlines current risk factors for osteoporosis and how to prevent and treat disease in lieu of study that identified potential health risk in long-term postmenpausal hormone replacement therapy; drugs Fosamax and Actonel, adequate vitamin D and calcium supplements and exercise are discussed as ways to arrest or diminish bone loss; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Last summer's surprising report from a large federal study relegating the use of postmenopausal hormone therapy to short-term relief of symptoms, not long-term health maintenance, left millions of women in a quandary: what should they do to keep...

docs.lead_paragraph: Based on their baby pictures, five New Mexico children would appear to be related. But instead, these babies were connected only by their birth defects and by sharing a genetic disorder that might have first occurred here about 400 years ago, when Spanish settlers first arrived. Now, a New Mexico doctor is piecing together the clues of this mysterious and newly detected ailment among a few families, and a local genealogist is trying to find a possible historical connection.

headline.main: 5 Birth-Defect Cases Tell a Centuries-Old Tale

docs.abstract: Dr Carol Clericuzio, pediatric clinical geneticist at University of New Mexico, is studying five separate known cases of yet unnamed genetic disorder possibly linked to Spanish settlers migrating to area 400 years ago; disease is believed to be founder effect and to have been silently carried for generations; only Nicole Armijo, age 7, is alive, other four children having died before they were three years old; Clericuzio hopes to identify gene that causes disorder; symptoms include dwarfism, small kidneys and recessed eyes; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Based on their baby pictures, five New Mexico children would appear to be related. But instead, these babies were connected only by their birth defects and by sharing a genetic disorder that might have first occurred here about 400 years ago, when...

docs.lead_paragraph: A panel of experts has recommended that tens of thousands of people be tested for a new indicator of heart disease. The indicator, C-reactive protein, is produced in the liver in response to injury or inflammation, and it can help identify people at higher risk for heart attack and stroke, including those with normal cholesterol. But the panel, convened by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the American Heart Association, stopped short of recommending the test for every adult and said that the test should not replace assessments of other risk factors, like cholesterol, high blood pressure and diabetes.

headline.main: New Test for Hearts at Risk: What It Can and Can't Do

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Thomas A Pearson, co-chairman of Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and American Heart Association's panel on C-reactive protein testing, discusses what factors indicate patients should be tested and defines high CRP as risk marker, not cause of heart disease; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A panel of experts has recommended that tens of thousands of people be tested for a new indicator of heart disease. The indicator, C-reactive protein, is produced in the liver in response to injury or inflammation, and it can help identify people at...

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: Interpersonal conflict on the job can make blood pressure soar -- say, for a New York City traffic enforcement agent writing a ticket or dealing with an angry motorist. But a new study of traffic agents in such situations found that those who felt that they had strong support from their supervisors had much smaller spikes in blood pressure than those who did not.
docs.abstract: Study published in journal Psychosomatic Medicine by Dr Elizbeth Brondolo of St John's University in Queens shows workers experience lower stress levels while working when they know they have support of boss or co-workers; effects of supportive environment were gauged through blood pressure levels in simulated and real work situations (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The PMDD Phenomenon: Breakthrough Treatments for Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder,'' by Dr. Diana L. Dell and Carol Svec. Contemporary Books, $14.95. ''Taking Back the Month,'' by Dr. Diana Taylor and Stacey Colino. Perigee, $14.95. Premenstrual suffering is not to be dismissed or taken lightly, as it has been in countless PMS jokes and in the more callous male view of it as an excuse for any moment of female ill temper.
docs.abstract: PMS, estimated to affect between 3 to 9 percent of menstruating women, is discussed and treatments of it and more severe PMDD are discussed in Dr Diana L Dell and Carol Svec book PMDD Phenomenon: Breakthrough Treatments for Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder; only drugs Sarafem and Zoloft are currently approved for disorder; Taking Back the Month by Dr Diana Taylor and Stacey Colino gives methods of treating PMS symptoms without drugs; diet, relaxation and emerging therapies such as herbs, nutritional supplements, diet and acupuncture are discussed; photos (S)
docs.snippet: ''The PMDD Phenomenon: Breakthrough Treatments for Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder,'' by Dr. Diana L. Dell and Carol Svec. Contemporary Books, $14.95.    ''Taking Back the Month,'' by Dr. Diana Taylor and Stacey Colino. Perigee, $14.95.     ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Habitual snoring and chronic headaches appear to go together, according to a study released yesterday. For the study, published in the journal Neurology, researchers surveyed 206 people who reported an average of 260 days with headaches a year, and a comparison group of 507 people who reported an average of 24 headache days.

headline.main: An Ugly Pair, Asleep and Awake

docs.abstract: Dr Ann I Scher, researcher at National Institute on Aging, reports in journal Neurology that people with chronic headaches are more than twice as likely to be snorers; snoring is not necessarily cause of headaches, but could provide link to other factors and possible treatment; drawing (S)
